1.title: Introduction
1.description: Genesis which means beginning. It tells the story of how the world began and how God created all things, including animals of different kind and human beings both male and female., Moses, the Prophet, and the leader of Israel was an author of Pentateuch. The first book is Genesis. He wrote Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers and Deuteronomy. All together known as Torah which means law., Bible doesn’t tell exactly when and where Genesis was written, but it was probably written by Moses during the years of Israelites encampment in the wilderness at Sinai., And it may be written to early Israelites after their Exodus from slavery in Egypt before they entered to the land of Canaan.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: The name of the book is Exodus which means departure. In the book of Exodus, the author describes Jacob and his family continuing to live in the region of Goshen which is in Egypt. Later, Pharaoh, king of Egypt made the Israelites enslaved, oppressed, suffered, and worked hard. But all this while, we could learn that God shows His faithfulness, power, love, holiness to the people. He made a covenant with the people of Israelites. This book is written by Moses. He was adopted by one of Pharaoh’s daughters. And as he grew up, he was well educated and well qualified in the house of the Pharaoh. Duration and place of writing After Israelites were out from Egypt towards the land of Canaan, they spent 40 years wandering in the wilderness. They did not reach Canaan land because of their disobedience to God. This is the most likely time for the writing of the book approximately dated between BC 1450- 1410. Recipients The recipients of this book would have been to the generation of Israelites after the Exodus while wandering in the wilderness. At Sinai, Moses wrote the book of Exodus to the people of Israel.

1.description: The book of Leviticus is a continuation of Israelites leaving the country of Egypt and their journey towards entering the promised land that the LORD has given. In all this while, LORD has been leading and helping the Israelites and reveal them that He is a Holy God and His people must live a holy life. Therefore, the laws in various aspects were instituted for the Israelites to follow and have a holy living., The word Leviticus derives from the tribe of Levi, who were chosen by the Lord to be His priests and worship leaders. The book explains about the importance of Levites’ responsibility in how they are to assist the people in worship, also taught and encouraged the people how to live a holy life.

According to the Biblical researchers, more likely Joshua the son of Nun, the assistant of Moses as leader over Israel, wrote much of this book. 1.title: Introduction
1.description: The sign for this book is misleading. It is not a book about people who make decisions in law courts. The book of Judges tells the stories of some of ancient Israel’s greatest leaders, called judges whom God raised to deliver Israelites from their enemies. The book of Judges narrates the history of Israel under these judges from the time they settled in the land of Canaan after Joshua's death to the birth of Samuel (approximately 1400–1000 B.C.). As the Israelites settled in the land of Canaan and lived among the people who were still there and worshiped many different gods. The Israelites often went astray from Yahweh to worship these gods. When the Israelites did this evil in the sight of Yahweh, he allowed the other people to defeat them. But when the Israelites repented and prayed to Yahweh, he sent judges who helped the Israelites defeat their enemies. This pattern happens many times in the book of Judges. It is possible that Samuel assembled some of the accounts from the period of the judges and that such prophets as Nathan and Gad, both of whom were associated with King David’s court, had a hand in editing the material and shaping the Book of Judges.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: 1.The book is named for its central character, a Moabite woman, who forsakes her pagan heritage in order to cling to the people of Israel and to the God of Israel. Ruth is the Hebrew title of this book means “friendship or association.” This book covers 30 years history. It is an incident that happened in the days of the judges., 2. Because of her faithfulness in a time of national faithlessness, God rewards her by giving her a new husband, a son, and a privileged position in the lineage of King David and Jesus the Messiah., 3. Ruth and Naomi are the major personalities in the first two chapters and Ruth and Boaz in the last two chapters. And in the first two chapters Ruth’s love is demonstrated and in the last two chapters Ruth’s love is rewarded. This book is an illustration of godliness, real faith and obedience that leads to blessings.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: The Book of II Samuel does not identify its author. Originally, the books of I and II Samuel were one book, later separated into two distinct books. Consequently, the first book ended with Saul's death and the second book commences with David's reign. In this book, it narrates how David ascended to kingship from the tribe of Judah.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: The book of Joel is part of the 12 Minor Prophets or Book of the Nevim of the Hebrew Scriptures and is itself a book in the Christian Old Testament).  Joel uses a recent disaster in Judah to teach his audience a lesson about the future. A locust plague had invaded the land, destroying every green thing in its path. Joel uses the locust invasion as the starting point of his sermon. Just like ‘locusts’ an army from the north would come to attack the nation, leaving behind devastation even more complete than that of the locusts.  Joel wrote to warn the people of Judah to repent and turn to the Lord before the Day of Judgement arrives. Joel assured the people that through repentance they would again receive the blessings of God.  The book of Joel teaches that God is powerful and He hears the combined prayers and fasting of God’s people during a time of great difficulty.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: The book of Obadiah is part of the 12 short books written by Prophets in the Christian Old Testament and Book of the Nevim of the Hebrew Scriptures. Obadiah, is the shortest book in the Old Testament., The Book of Obadiah is written by Obadiah the Prophet of God who condemn Edom for sins against both God and Israel. The Hebrew name ‘obadyah’ means “servant of Yahweh”., The Edomites are descendants of Esau and the Israelites are descendants of his twin brother, Jacob. A quarrel between the brothers has affected their descendants for over 1,000 years., The major theme of Obadiah is a declaration of Edom’s doom because of its arrogance and cruelty to Judah. The secondary theme of Obadiah is the future restoration of Israel and faithfulness of Yahweh to His covenant promises.

To accomplish his purpose Matthew emphasis Jesus’ royal genealogy. The Gospel of Matthew was written between 65 and 75 AD in Antioch of Northern Syria.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: 1.The Gospel of Mark consists of 16 chapters, written by John Mark. According to the testimony of the early church fathers, John Mark is an associate of the apostles. He was able to learn about the life of Jesus directly from apostle Peter and wrote in large part on the information given by him.2. Mark was the son of Mary, cousin of Barnabas, and a colleague of the Apostle Paul.3. Purpose of his writing was to present Jesus as the ‘Servant Redeemer’ as prophesied in the Old Testament. 4.The Gospel of Mark was written in between 55 & 65 AD. Among the four gospels, Mark’s gospel was written first. And it is written in Rome.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: The Gospel of Luke is consisting of 24 chapters and is written by Luke, a physician, and a Gentile.He was a close companion of the Apostle Paul in his missionary journey also remained with Paul during Paul’s imprisonment in Rome.When and where; Luke began writing his account on Jesus probably at Caesarea and finished it in Rome between AD 65 and 70.Luke was a Greek, a gentile, therefore, he has written his gospel in a way that gentiles (non-Jew) would easily understand.In addition to this gospel Luke also wrote the book of Acts. Luke was a physician, missionary (associated with Paul in his mission) and above all, a historian. He was very careful both in his gospel and in the book of Acts to give accurate historical details. Luke wrote this historical account on Jesus to Theophilus probably a Roman official to establish him in the faith in Jesus Christ. Theophilus was a believer and then the purpose of the book was edification of the saint.Luke presents Jesus as ‘Son of Man’ ‘Perfect man’ and the key words in this gospel is ‘Salvation’ and ‘Son of Man’.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: The apostle John is believed to be the author of the gospel of John. He was one of Jesus’ 12 Apostles and was one of the few apostles closest to Jesus. He was an eyewitness of the ministry of the Lord Jesus. He was the only disciple to witness Christ’s death on the cross. John refers to himself as "the disciple whom Jesus loved". He is the son of Zebedee and the brother of James. He was a Jew. one of the few apostles closest to Jesus. He was an eyewitness of the ministry of the Lord Jesus. He was the only disciple to witness Christ’s death on the cross. John refers to himself as "the disciple whom Jesus loved". He is the son of Zebedee and the brother of James. He was a Jew., Date and place of writing:- , John's Gospel is generally considered to be the last of the four Gospels to be written. The Book of John is an eyewitness account of Jesus’ ministry. John likely wrote his Gospel account between A.D. 70 and A.D. 95. The place of the writing is generally thought to be most likely Ephesus., Recipients:-, John wrote to an audience of both Jews as indicated by his focus on the fulfillment of the Old Testament promises about the Messiah and descriptions of Jewish tradition, as well as Gentiles as indicated by his referring to Jesus as God who became flesh., Theme and Purpose:-, The Gospel of John was written to prove that Jesus is the Son of God and the Messiah. He has written this gospel to prove that the Messiah is the source of eternal life to all who believe in him., John begins the gospel by presenting Jesus Christ as God. The gospel ends with the statement of the disciple Thomas proclaiming that Jesus is Lord and God., John records seven signs in this gospel which are meant to demonstrate that Jesus is the Messiah, what He did for us, and help bring a person to faith in the Messiah., Key verses:-, John 20:31, “But these are written that you may believe that Jesus is the Messiah, the Son of God and that by believing you may have life in his name.”, John 3:16, John 12:36, John 14:6, John 14:12

1.title: Introduction
1.description: An introduction to the ACTS OF APOSTLES, AUTHORSHIP,Luke, the physician, is the author of this book. Luke was an eyewitness to many of the events in Acts. Traditionally he has been viewed as a gentile, he was primarily an evangelist. He wrote the Gospel of Luke and the book of Acts and accompanied Paul in missionary work (Col. 4:14; 2 Tim. 4:11; Phil. 24).DATE AND PLACE OF WRITING,Acts is approximately dated between AD 63 and 70. Key places for the writing may be Jerusalem, Samaria, Lydda, Joppa, Antioch, Iconium, lystra, Derbe, Phillipi,Thessalonica, Berea, Athens, Corinth, Ephesus, Caesarea, Malta, Rome.RECIPIENTS, Luke wrote to Theophilus (Acts 1:1). The address that Luke utilizes for Theophilus, “most excellent” in 'Luke 1' suggests that this individual occupied some high-ranking status in society.

1.title: Intoduction
1.description: This book is a letter that the Apostle Paul wrote to the Christians at Ephesus. Ephesus was an important commercial center (Acts: 18:19) of the Roman province of Asia Minor. In his second missionary journey Apostle Paul visited and ministered in Ephesus (with Priscilla and Aquila Acts: 18:18-21). Apostle Paul spent about three years in Ephesus during his third missionary journey (Acts 20:31; 19:8-10). He supported himself by his tent-making trade (Acts 20:34). After his departure from Ephesus, he sent Timothy there to continue his work (1Timothy. 1:3). Apostle Paul wrote the epistle to the Ephesians from Rome while in prison around AD 60-62. Ephesians teaches about God's salvation through Jesus the Messiah, the purpose and plan of God for the church, and practical Christian life.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: An Introduction to the First Letter to the Thessalonians, AUTHORSHIP, Paul wrote 1 Thessalonians, writing with the agreement of Silvanus and Timothy. Paul was from the city of Tarsus and a Roman citizen. He had been known as Saul in his early life. Before becoming a believer, Saul was a Pharisee and a member of the Sanhedrin. He persecuted Believers. After he became a believer, Paul traveled several times throughout the Roman Empire, telling people about Jesus, supporting his ministry by making tents., DATE, PLACE & RECIPIENT, Paul probably wrote this letter in A.D. 49–51 while staying in the city of Corinth during his second missionary journey. He wrote this letter to the believers in Thessalonica.

The beginning of the epistle also contains a greeting from Silas and Timothy.PLACE, DATE AND RECIPIENTS Shortly after writing 1 Thessalonians, the apostle Paul received a report (2 Thessalonians. 3:17) that the Thessalonian church had accepted the strange claim that “the day of the Lord has come” (2:1-2). Paul sent them a second letter in A.D. 49–51. He was probably in Corinth at the time.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: AUTHORSHIP AND RECIPIENT The letter’s author is Paul, the texts of 1 Timothy clearly state that it was written by Apostle Paul (1 Tim 1:1). First Timothy is so named because it is addressed to Timothy, Paul's traveling companion and assistant on his missionary journeys. Both Timothy and the church as a whole are the intended recipients of 1 Timothy. DATE AND PLACE OF WRITING This letter is approximately dated between AD 62 - 66. When Paul left Timothy in Ephesus, he continued to Macedonia, where he wrote to him. (1Tim. 1:3; 3:14,15). PURPOSE Paul wrote to Timothy to encourage him in his responsibility for overseeing the work of the Ephesian church and possibly the other churches in the province of Asia (1 Tim. 1:3) This letter lays the foundation for ordaining elders (1 Tim. 3:1-7) and provides guidance for ordaining people into offices of the church (1 Tim. 3: 8-13). In essence, 1 Timothy is a leadership manual for church organization and administration.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: Paul’s Second Epistle to Timothy is one of the epistles that gives advice on matters of church government and discipline, along with 1 Timothy and Titus. Paul wrote the epistle sometime between A.D. 64 and 67. during his final imprisonment in Rome shortly before his martyrdom. Paul was aware that his time was short, and he desired to see Timothy, whom Paul considered as son. Paul was concerned about the welfare of the churches during the time of persecution under Nero, and he advices Timothy, continue to follow the teachings of Jesus the Messiah and to teach and preach the true gospel and endure the suffering. By studying this book, you will learn fundamental teachings and principles that can help you live faithfully to God as you experience the dangerous times of the last days.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: The book of Titus in the Bible is a letter written by Paul to Titus consisting of three chapters. Titus was a Gentile and a Co-worker of the apostle Paul among the non-Jewish people. In this letter, Paul called himself as servant of God and the Apostle of Christ. Apostle Paul accompanied Titus to the Crete Island which is the largest Island in the country of Greece. The reason Paul left Titus in Crete Island is to complete the unfinished work for the Churches., Duration and Place of Writing, The book was written approximately dated between A.D 62-65., Paul wrote this letter to Titus from Nicopolis after he was released from his first imprisonment in Rome.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: The Book of Philemon was authored by the apostle Paul, as indicated in Philemon 1:1. This epistle is addressed to Philemon, a believer residing at Colossae. Within this letter, Paul expresses that he is sending Onesimus back to Philemon to be with him. Onesimus was Philemon’s slave, and he would be coming to Colossae with Tychicus who would be delivering Paul’s letter to Philemon. Notably, Paul wrote this letter with his own hand, showing that it means it is something very important.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: The Apostle John, son of Zebedee, is believed to be the author of the epistles of 1, 2, and 3 John. He was an eyewitness of the ministry of the Lord Jesus. He was one of Jesus’ 12 Apostles. John describes himself as "the disciple whom Jesus loved". The Epistles of John are also called Johannine epistles or the Letters of John. John wrote the Gospel of John, three epistles of John, as well as the book of Revelation.

1.title: Introduction
1.description: An introduction to the epistle of Jude, This epistle was written by Jude, the brother of Jesus, born after Jesus, a son of Joseph and Mary. Jesus’ brothers came to believe in Jesus as the Son of God later, after his resurrection., Jude wanted to expose the false teachers who had entered the Church and also, he wanted to encourage the Christians to stand firm in faith and guard themselves from the false teachings., Although it is one of the shortest books in the New Testament, the Epistle of Jude contains information that is not found anywhere else in the Bible. Jude portrayed Jesus as ‘Our Protector'., This epistle was probably written between A.D. 60 and 69 in Jerusalem.
